verses.text: A Psalm of Asaph. Truly God \add is\add* good to Israel, \add even\add* to such as are of a clean heart.
But as for me, my feet were almost gone; my steps had well nigh slipped.
For I was envious at the foolish, \add when\add* I saw the prosperity of the wicked.
For \add there are\add* no bands in their death: but their strength \add is\add* firm.
They \add are\add* not in trouble \add as other\add* men; neither are they afflicted like \add other\add* men.
Therefore pride encompasseth them as a chain; violence covereth them \add as\add* a garment.
Their eyes stand out with fatness: they have more than heart could wish.
They are corrupt, and speak wickedly \add concerning\add* oppression: they speak loftily.
They set their mouth against the heavens, and their tongue walketh through the earth.
Therefore his people return hither: and waters of a full \add cup\add* are wrung out to them.
And they say, How doth God know? and is there knowledge in the Most High?
Behold, these \add are\add* the ungodly, who prosper in the world; they increase \add in\add* riches.
Verily I have cleansed my heart \add in\add* vain, and washed my hands in innocence.
For all the day long have I been afflicted, and chastened every morning.
If I say, I will speak thus; behold, I should offend \add against\add* the generation of thy children.
When I thought to know this, it \add was\add* too painful for me;
Until I went into the sanctuary of God; \add then\add* I understood their end.
Surely thou didst set them in slippery places: thou didst cast them down into destruction.
How are they \add brought\add* into desolation, as in a moment! they are utterly consumed with terrors.
As a dream when \add one\add* awaketh; \add so\add* , O LORD, when thou awakest, thou wilt despise their image.
Thus my heart was grieved, and I was pricked in my reins.
So foolish \add was\add* I, and ignorant: I was \add as\add* a beast before thee.
Nevertheless I \add am\add* continually with thee: thou hast held \add me\add* by my right hand.
Thou wilt guide me with thy counsel, and afterward receive me \add to\add* glory.
Whom have I in heaven \add but thee\add* ? and \add there is\add* none upon earth \add that\add* I desire besides thee.
My flesh and my heart faileth: \add but\add* God \add is\add* the strength of my heart, and my portion for ever.
For lo, they that are far from thee shall perish: thou hast destroyed all them that go astray from thee.
But \add it is\add* good for me to draw near to God: I have put my trust in the Lord GOD, that I may declare all thy works.
